title: Avioane Craiova IAR-93 Vultur
content: [{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Avioane Craiova IAR-93 Vultur, also known as the Eagle, is a twinjet, subsonic aircraft developed by Romania and Yugoslavia in the 1970s. This joint development aimed to create a versatile aircraft capable of fulfilling various roles, including close support, ground attack, tactical reconnaissance, and low-level interception. The Romanian version of the aircraft was manufactured by Avioane Craiova as the IAR-93, while the Yugoslav counterpart was built by Soko and known as the Soko J-22 Orao. Let's explore the development, features, and variants of this remarkable aircraft."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Development of the IAR-93 Vultur"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"In May 1971, Romania and Yugoslavia signed a bilateral agreement to embark on the YuRom R&D program, which aimed to create a light subsonic aircraft for ground attack and tactical reconnaissance missions. The program managers, Dipl. Dr. Engineer Teodor Zamfirescu and Colonel Vidoje Knežević, oversaw the development of the aircraft. The primary goal was to produce an aircraft that was domestically manufactured, easy to maintain, and compatible with Western avionics."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"One of the initial challenges faced by the development team was finding a suitable jet engine for the aircraft. Initially, they explored the possibility of using modern British-made engines, but the licensing for their manufacture in Eastern Europe was not feasible. As a result, they decided to utilize the Rolls-Royce Viper engine, which had been developed in the early 1950s by Armstrong Siddeley. Although not the ideal choice, it was the only available option at the time."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Features of the IAR-93 Vultur"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The IAR-93 Vultur was designed as a conventional twin-engine, high-mounted wing monoplane with swept wings. It featured a tricycle landing gear, aerodynamic brakes, and a cockpit located slightly forward of two side air intakes. The aircraft incorporated a \"zero-zero\" ejection seat manufactured by Martin-Baker, ensuring the safety of the pilots in emergency situations."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The avionics and armament of the IAR-93 Vultur combined Western and Eastern technologies. While it did not reach the same level as the SEPECAT Jaguar, it represented a significant technological advancement for the aviation industry in both Romania and Yugoslavia. It was the first jet aircraft developed and designed by the domestic aviation industry in Romania."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Variants of the IAR-93 Vultur"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The IAR-93 Vultur had several major variants, each with its own unique features and capabilities. The initial production version was the IAR-93A, equipped with non-afterburning Viper Mk 632-41 turbojets. It included 15 pre-production aircraft and 35 production models, with 26 single-seaters and 9 dual-control two-seaters. The IAR-93A entered service in 1981 and played a crucial role in replacing the older MiG-15 and MiG-17 aircraft in the fighter-bomber role."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Another variant was the IAR-93MB, which retained the non-afterburning Viper 632-41 engine but incorporated a different fuselage design. It served as an upgraded version of the IAR-93A and was primarily used for advanced flying and weapon training. The IAR-93MB was delivered starting in 1982, with 15 single-seaters produced."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The most refined version of the IAR-93 Vultur was the IAR-93B. It featured afterburning Viper Mk 633-47 engines, increased internal fuel capacity, upgraded hardpoints, and a revised wing design with leading edge extensions. This version first flew in 1985 and entered service in 1987. A total of 27 single-seaters and 7 dual-control twin-seaters were built."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Operational History and Retirement"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The IAR-93 Vultur served in the Romanian Air Force, specifically the 67th Fighter-Bomber Regiment and the 49th Fighter-Bomber Regiment based in Craiova and Ianca, respectively. However, the aircraft's operational history was cut short due to external factors. Following the outbreak of the war in Yugoslavia and the UN embargo, the IAR-93 program came to an end in Romania in 1992. Approximately 75 aircraft were still in service at that time, but most were subsequently retired and mothballed."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Some surviving IAR-93 aircraft can still be found in Romanian museums or serving as gate guards. Notably, the Romanian National Aviation Museum in Bucharest exhibits an Avioane Craiova IAR-93A(DC) Vultur aircraft. However, the majority of the remaining aircraft have been dismantled, with their engines and other equipment removed. Some are available for sale, while others have been scrapped."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Specifications of the IAR-93B"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The IAR-93B variant of the Vultur had specific specifications that contributed to its impressive performance. It had a length of 48.9 feet, a wingspan of 30.5 feet, and a height of 14.9 feet. The empty weight of the aircraft was 12,675 pounds, with a maximum take-off weight of 22,030 pounds. The power was provided by two Turbomecanica/Orao (Rolls-Royce) Viper Mk 644-47 turbojet engines, delivering 4,000 pounds of dry thrust and 5,000 pounds with the afterburner engaged. The aircraft had a maximum speed of 680 miles per hour and a cruising speed of approximately 675 miles per hour. Its range was 825 miles, and it had a rate-of-climb of 3,900 feet per minute, reaching a service ceiling of 44,600 feet."}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Conclusion"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Avioane Craiova IAR-93 Vultur represented a significant achievement for the Romanian and Yugoslavian aviation industries. Developed to decrease dependency on Soviet equipment, this twinjet aircraft fulfilled multiple roles, including ground attack, tactical reconnaissance, and low-level interceptor missions. Despite its retirement in 1992, the IAR-93 left a lasting impact on Romania's aviation history. Through its variants, it showcased the capabilities and advancements achieved by the domestic aviation industry. The IAR-93 Vultur will forever be remembered as an essential part of Romania's military aviation heritage."}]}]

title: Williams FW14B one of the most advanced F1 cars
content: [{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"When we talk about Williams in F1, we talk about history, legend, a team created from scratch by Sir Frank Williams. The recent history of the English team has been in decline, which certainly does not do justice to a team capable of winning a remarkable 9 constructor titles."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The car debuted in the first race of 1991 and, despite showing great potential, the initial outings were marred by reliability issues linked to the gearbox. The 1991 season served as a shakedown period, with the latter part of the season bringing the first victories. In 1992, the car was slightly modified and perfected with a Version B: reliability issues were resolved, active suspension improved, and from thereon, the FW14B marked an embarrassing dominance, earning the nickname: the machine from another planet."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"AERODYNAMICS AND CHASSIS"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The aerodynamics of the Williams FW14 were quite distinct from rival teams, if we may say so: Adrian Newey brought in concepts seen in a raw form on the Leyton House car, distinguished by an extremely narrow chassis. Even the cockpit was quite tight, and the bodywork enveloped the top of the steering wheel entirely. The mounting of the front suspension's strut was encased in a kind of \"bulb\" in the bodywork, a characteristic identical to the Leyton House design. One of the main innovations of the Williams FW14 was the raised chassis (a carbon monocoque) at the bottom, which then merged into a high and narrow nose. The raised chassis allowed for increased airflow under the car, then directed towards the radiators' intake. The side pods were very low, and the compact rear end tapered down towards the \"Coca-Cola\" area to enhance the extractor's efficiency. The car, as a whole, appeared very sleek, free from clutter, almost resembling a military jet from a frontal view. An aerodynamic gem introduced by Adrian Newey was the wing endplate wrapping internally around the front tire. The endplate was quite extensive, specially designed to maintain laminar flow and guide it around the front wheels. This reduced turbulence and allowed for a \"clean\" fluid dynamic profile even in the car's central area. The diagram below illustrates the intricate detail of the long-flow deflector of the front wing."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"SUSPENSION"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The true ace up Williams' sleeve was undoubtedly the active suspension, a technological solution that etched its mark in F1 history, capable, through an electronic control unit, of maintaining the car's optimal balance at every point on the track. Cars lacking this system were destined to lose. In 1992, Williams not only managed to make this system effective but more importantly, made it reliable. The British car in '92 employed hydro-pneumatic independent front suspension. Utilizing a push-rod layout, the entire suspension system was exclusively developed by Frank Williams' team. A hydraulic circuit connected the suspension struts via actuators, with an electronic control unit regulating the correct ride height. The small cover above the front suspension struts allowed for quick adjustments to the \"inboard\" shock absorbers and tie rods. In the illustration, we see the entire working of the active suspension on the Williams FW14: Actuators are shown in yellow, hydraulically connected to the struts and suspension arms, the electronic components are in green, and the large fluid reservoir is in blue, positioned behind the Renault engine."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"ENGINE AND GEARBOX"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"In terms of horsepower, the Renault engine powering the Williams FW14B might not have been the most potent, but it certainly was extremely reliable. Generating around 760 horsepower, the Renault RS4 engine was a naturally aspirated 67-degree V10 with a displacement of 3493 cc. The Williams-Renault partnership is one of the most successful in F1 history, dominating much of the '90s. Since the end of this collaboration, Williams' descent began, and the team hasn't secured a title since 1997, the last year of the Anglo-French partnership. Adrian Newey has always favored the naturally aspirated engines from the French manufacturer, a choice he continued at Red Bull, where he also secured multiple world titles. The semi-automatic gearbox introduced in '91 had its fair share of mechanical issues during the season, preventing Williams from fully challenging the Senna-driven McLaren Honda, which went on to win both titles. These problems were resolved by 1992, and the 6-speed transverse gearbox finally became reliable."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Williams FW14 will forever be etched in F1 history, marking an era by radically changing the approach to performance optimization. The car designed by Patrick Head and Adrian Newey dominated the 1992 and 1993 seasons in an embarrassing manner. The Federation banned the use of active suspension at the end of 1993, but despite this, Williams secured further titles in '96 and '97. The British team left an indelible mark on a decade, shifting the focus of other teams' designers towards an exhaustive search for aerodynamic gains, ultimately reshaping F1's technical future."}]}]

title: Http 1.0 protocol explained
content: [{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The "},{"text":"Hypertext Transfer Protocol","bold":true},{"text":" ("},{"text":"HTTP","bold":true},{"text":") is an "},{"type":"a","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_layer","target":"_blank","children":[{"text":"application layer"}],"id":"j5p3t"},{"text":" protocol in the "},{"type":"a","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite","target":"_blank","children":[{"text":"Internet protocol suite"}],"id":"pkiza"},{"text":" model for distributed, collaborative, "},{"type":"a","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypermedia","target":"_blank","children":[{"text":"hypermedia"}],"id":"b179r"},{"text":" information systems."}],"id":"z3jbq"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Over the years, the HTTP protocol has gained immense popularity and has solidified its position as one of the fundamental cornerstones of the internet. Since its inception in 1991, HTTP has undergone continuous evolution and enhancement. In this article, we will dive into the first version of Http."}],"id":"41g17"},{"type":"h1","id":"hjz9r","children":[{"text":"HTTP 1.0:"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Http 1.0 is the first version that was introduced in the late 1996 and it had these elements:"}],"id":"nivrb"},{"type":"p","id":"cq4vk","children":[{"text":"Not persistent connection"}],"undefined":2,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Host header optional"}],"id":"40ycg","listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"listStart":2},{"type":"p","id":"d9w0p","listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"listStart":3,"children":[{"text":"Limited support for caching"}]},{"type":"p","id":"t0mh7","listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"listStart":4,"children":[{"text":"Lack of Encryption  "}]},{"type":"h2","id":"hun3g","children":[{"text":"Not persistent connection:"}]},{"type":"p","id":"ya0xc","children":[{"text":"the Http not persistent connection is an Tcp connection where for every resource sent: the connection is opened and closed and this process brings unnecessary congestion to the network."}]},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/k5euni387bz053ckyvlnp--410x607.png","bytes":41136,"width":277,"height":410,"maxWidth":410,"maxHeight":607,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"i7mex"},{"type":"p","id":"aggz2","children":[{"text":"http 1.0 connection"}]},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Example with resources:"}],"id":"dhs43"},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/09s5zy12h9ai5zeraz3ju--1364x442.png","bytes":195387,"width":640,"height":207,"maxWidth":1364,"maxHeight":442,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"t32lh"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Http resouces"}],"id":"6xvn9"},{"type":"p","id":"bdk3p","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/djo193ewug11l7np3i7gr--1368x738.png","bytes":92373,"width":640,"height":345,"maxWidth":1368,"maxHeight":738,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"6fu89"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Wireshark Http resources"}],"id":"3m63l"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Wireshark Analyze: (repeat this process 4 times):"}],"id":"tx699"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}],"id":"kw37l"},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/qso1vchc5395rkmc9v6wp--1368x738.png","bytes":384640,"width":640,"height":345,"maxWidth":1368,"maxHeight":738,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"2dj4z"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Tcp connection establishment output_1.png (Three way hand shake opening)"}],"id":"33ut2"},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/pugjulq8l1iwuxqwqhakr--1368x738.png","bytes":391440,"width":640,"height":345,"maxWidth":1368,"maxHeight":738,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"r4n7l"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Tcp connection termination output_1.png (Three way hand shake closure)"}],"id":"aqng2"},{"type":"p","id":"m63eb","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","id":"19xlv","children":[{"text":"All the package that are in between the tcp establishment and termination are the image data "},{"text":"\"TCP Segments\"","bold":true}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"You can see a basic protocol implementation here: "},{"type":"a","url":"https://github.com/LuccaGugescu/python-http1.0","children":[{"text":"python-http1.0"}],"id":"tktha"},{"text":""}],"id":"w5z2f"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Host header optional"}],"id":"mlx1i"},{"type":"p","id":"d9z7p","children":[{"text":"Http 1.0 does not officially require a Host header and many applications (proxies) expect to see the Host header regardless of the protocol version."}]},{"type":"p","id":"wbfp4","children":[{"text":"Example:"}]},{"type":"code_block","children":[{"type":"code_line","id":"229ao","children":[{"text":"GET / HTTP/1.0"}]},{"type":"code_line","id":"judy0","children":[{"text":"Host: www.yourWebsite.com"}]},{"type":"code_line","indent":1,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"0chiz"}],"id":"qr2u1"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Limited support for caching"}],"id":"mmvtq"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"HTTP 1.0 had support for caching only via the header: If-Modified-Since and not using the "},{"text":"entity tag","italic":true},{"text":" like Http 1.1 which is more performant"}],"id":"baz8l"},{"type":"p","id":"99k8k","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Lack of Encryption"}],"id":"lc5yj"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Http1.0 doesn't support encryption which means that all the data is sent as plain text on the network and everyone with a network sniffer software can read the data sent."}],"id":"3cjds"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}],"id":"dq98r"}]

title: Reasons why integrals are so useful
content:
[{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Integrals are a fundamental concept in mathematics, particularly in calculus, and they are incredibly useful for several reasons:"}],"id":"7brbb"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Finding Area and Accumulated Quantity:
Integrals are often used to calculate the area under curves or the accumulated quantity of something over an interval.
For example, you can use integrals to find the area under a graph of a function, which has applications in geometry, physics, and engineering.
A practical example is the ability to calculate the distance traveled from a velocity function or find the total charge in an electrical circuit."}],"id":"y9wtt"},{"type":"p","id":"pfhx6","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Modeling and Analysis:
Integrals are a powerful tool for modeling and analyzing continuous processes. Many natural phenomena, such as motion, heat transfer, and population growth, involve continuous changes over time or space. Integrals allow us to study and understand these processes by quantifying their behavior."}],"id":"f9xsm"},{"type":"p","id":"ya7kh","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Derivatives and Antiderivatives:
Integrals are closely related to derivatives. The process of finding an integral is essentially the reverse of finding a derivative.
This connection is significant because it allows us to solve differential equations, which describe how quantities change over time or space.
Integrals provide a way to go from information about rates of change to information about the original quantities themselves."}],"id":"0bwnh"},{"type":"p","id":"it86b","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Probability and Statistics:
In probability theory, integrals are used to calculate probabilities by integrating probability density functions. In statistics, integrals are employed to calculate expected values, variances, and other statistical measures. Integrals play a fundamental role in both fields, allowing us to make sense of randomness and uncertainty."}],"id":"2dtm0"},{"type":"p","id":"nsc2t","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Engineering and Physics:
Integrals are extensively used in engineering and physics to solve complex problems. They are crucial for solving equations related to motion, electromagnetism, fluid dynamics, and many other physical phenomena. Engineers and physicists rely on integral calculus to design and analyze systems and predict their behavior."}],"id":"ll562"},{"type":"p","id":"6ebso","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Optimization:
Integrals are also used for optimization problems. In economics, for example, integrals can be employed to find the maximum or minimum values of functions, which is vital in decision-making and resource allocation."}],"id":"mvidl"},{"type":"p","id":"1pvlu","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Quantifying Change:
Integrals allow us to quantify how a quantity changes over time or space. This is essential for understanding rates of change, trends, and patterns in various fields, including economics, biology, and environmental sciences."}],"id":"i4t08"}]

title: Von Neuman Architecture
content: [{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The Von Neumann architecture was proposed in "},{"text":"1945","bold":true},{"text":" and it took several years for a physical computer to be built based on it, the only available option was Harvard architecture which was developed in "},{"text":"1939","bold":true},{"text":"."}],"id":"yg97v"},{"type":"h1","id":"17cil","children":[{"text":"How Cpu works:"}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"As technology has progressed, computers have become indispensable in our daily lives."}],"id":"m548j"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"They are capable of carrying out instructions and efficiently handling data processing and transfer. At the heart of every computer is the central processing unit (CPU), which is also referred to as the central processor or a core. The CPU serves as the computer's brain, responsible for fetching, decoding, and executing instructions accurately. It consists of essential components, including the control unit (which manages program instructions), registers (for data storage), and an arithmetic logic unit (ALU) that handles calculations."}],"id":"h74fe"},{"type":"p","id":"4e2gh","children":[{"text":"Typically, information is transmitted to the CPU through an electrical connection known as a bus. For example, a data bus is responsible for transmitting data, while an address bus conveys the memory address of the data. The organization of these computer components and the principles governing their functioning are collectively known as computer architecture."}]},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"There are two types of computer architecture: Von Neumann and Harvard architecture. The Von Neumann architecture mainly has one shared program and data memory while Harvard architecture has two separate memories where one is meant for program code and the other for data."}],"id":"sxx2o"},{"type":"h1","children":[{"text":"Von Neumann vs Harvard Architecture:"}],"id":"dtyd0"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"The main difference between the Von Neumann Architecture and Harvard is the data and instructions storage location, Von Neumann uses only a memory location to store both, Harvard has two separate memories(instruction memory and data memory)."}],"id":"marjj"},{"type":"p","id":"07ahg","children":[{"text":"Another difference is the bus, von Neumann uses one bus for both address and data transfer, Harvard architecture has two separate buses."}]},{"type":"p","id":"lprd6","children":[{"text":""}]},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/so2g04ws19kf1ist4imgd--1063x235.png","bytes":193681,"width":640,"height":141,"maxWidth":1063,"maxHeight":235,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"pfiru"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Harvard Architecture"}],"id":"3m2hr"},{"type":"cloud_image","url":"https://files.portive.com/f/getiverse/9fvl2g6cpydexye0hynft--800x312.png","bytes":139242,"width":494,"height":193,"maxWidth":800,"maxHeight":312,"children":[{"text":""}],"id":"00sow"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Von Neumann Architecture"}],"id":"3pxr0"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Von Neumann Pros:"}],"id":"a797f"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"It occupies less physical space."}],"id":"k6paj","undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1},{"type":"p","id":"lo0d1","undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"children":[{"text":"Managing a single memory block is a more straightforward and attainable task."}],"listStart":2},{"type":"p","id":"ld1z1","undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"listStart":3,"children":[{"text":"Cheaper to use"}]},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Von Neumann Cons:"}],"id":"vubpu"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Fetch rate: Data and instructions share the same data bus, despite often having varying requirements for fetching, creating potential inefficiencies."}],"id":"p5ubo","undefined":5,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1},{"type":"p","id":"4umiy","undefined":5,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"children":[{"text":"Data bus speed: The CPU operates significantly faster than the data bus, resulting in frequent periods of inactivity (known as the Von Neumann bottleneck)."}],"listStart":2},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Shared memory: A malfunctioning program can overwrite another program in memory, potentially leading to a crash."}],"id":"tx3s4"},{"type":"p","id":"otwe1","children":[{"text":"Memory leaks: Certain flawed programs may neglect to release memory once they're done with it, potentially causing a computer crash due to insufficient available memory."}],"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Von Neumann Use:"}],"id":"wv7bm"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"the von Neumann Architecuture is wildy used in the computer industry."}],"id":"3av3w"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Harvard Pros:"}],"id":"izsuo"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Less chance of data corruption."}],"undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"id":"twspi"},{"type":"p","undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"children":[{"text":"High performance."}],"listStart":2,"id":"h1wzm"},{"type":"p","undefined":3,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"listStart":3,"id":"fp1o4","children":[{"text":"Greater memory bandwidth"}]},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Harvard Cons:"}],"id":"u8juh"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Complexity"}],"undefined":5,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"id":"on987"},{"type":"p","undefined":5,"listStyleType":"disc","indent":1,"children":[{"text":"Higher cost of implementation"}],"listStart":2,"id":"kvb4z"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Harvard Use:"}],"id":"h7ubg"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Harvard architecture is used primary for "},{"text":"small embedded computers and signal processing (DSP).","bold":true}],"id":"fobvo"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":""}],"id":"xx758"}]

title: How to build a rocket
content: [{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"How to build a rocket"}],"id":"rfhtb"},{"type":"p","id":"28q6z","children":[{"text":"To build a rocket you need","bold":true}]},{"type":"p","id":"qdywa","children":[{"text":"Hegehsjd","bold":true,"italic":true}]},{"type":"p","id":"wkabf","children":[{"bold":true,"italic":true,"text":""}]},{"type":"table","children":[{"type":"tr","children":[{"type":"td","children":[{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Shgs"}],"id":"clv29"}],"id":"pgney"},{"type":"td","children":[{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"BsvsHHhjsbsg"}],"id":"k2thy"}],"id":"8ogda"}],"id":"sv9zj"},{"type":"tr","children":[{"type":"td","children":[{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Hhjhwhsgs"}],"id":"3kh5b"}],"id":"9q88z"},{"type":"td","children":[{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Sbbsshgs"}],"id":"o3zw2"}],"id":"red0x"}],"id":"zxw56"}],"id":"4zzt7"},{"type":"h2","children":[{"text":"Nzbshsjsjs"}],"id":"k0gzl"},{"type":"p","children":[{"text":"Jshshsjjwhsgshjsjs"}],"id":"z3cam"},{"type":"p","id":"e2hik","children":[{"text":"GGsgshjsjsksk"}]},{"type":"p","id":"u06xs","children":[{"text":"GsGsgshsjjs"}]},{"type":"p","id":"9jm6n","children":[{"text":"GGsgsiksksjgs"}]},{"type":"p","id":"6di3m","children":[{"text":"YYshshhs"}]}]
